Award.AwardTitle: CPS: TTP Option: Synergy: Learning and Adaption in Pediatric Robotics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Children affected by neurological conditions (e.g., Cerebral Palsy, Muscular Atrophy, Spina Bifida and Severe head trauma) often develop significant disabilities including impaired motor control. In many cases, walking becomes a non-functional and exhausting skill that demands the use of the aids or the substitution of function, such as wheelchair. This usually cause these children not to acquire locomotion skills, and consequently to lose their independence. However, it is well understood that bipedal locomotion, an essential human characteristic, ensures the best physiological motor pattern acquisition. For this reason, in children with neurological and neuromuscular diseases, independent walking is a significant rehabilitation goal that must be pursued in a specific temporal window due to the plasticity of central nervous system. In other words, children with neurological conditions have a small window of time to acquire locomotion skills through assisted walking rehearsals. The objective of this research work is to create and experimentally validate a set of technologies that form the framework for the development of adaptive, self-balancing, and modular exoskeleton robotics systems for children with neurological disorders. It is our belief that the exoskeleton (and its associated infrastructure) resulting from this research will offer an effective tool to promote locomotion skill acquisition, and in general health, during a critical period in the early life of children with neurological conditions.


This research proposal develops a data-driven human-machine modeling specific to physiological conditions. This creates regression models that predict the user behavior without explicit modeling the complex human musculoskeletal dynamics and motor control mechanism. Additionally this research project formulates a safe adaptive control problem as a model predictive control (MPC) problem. In this method, an optimal input sequence is computed by solving a constrained finite-time optimal control problem where exoskeleton intrusion (input from exoskeleton) is minimized to maximize the user's intent to promote learning. This project further develops a novel approach for stabilizing and preventing fall of the exoskeleton and the child as a whole. This method allows a child wearing an exoskeleton to learn locomotion skills described above with less likelihood of falls. This research project furthermore evaluates the developed technologies in terms of efficiency and efficacy and creates a novel fun game using exoskeleton for children to promote locomotion skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop a set of technologies that lead to exoskeletons that promote the walking skills among children affected by neurological conditions (e.g., Cerebral Palsy, Spinal Muscular Atrophy, Spina Bifida and Severe head trauma). We have designed and built an experimental pediatric exoskeleton system.  The device is adjustable in terms of size (femur, tibia and hip length) and power. The device battery allows for 4 hours of continuous (or 8 hours of intermittent) locomotion.  A pediatric exoskeleton which resulted from this research work has the following two novel characteristics:

1)        The exoskeleton hardware is under-actuated.   We have shown that it is possible to create a desired trajectory through two actuators at the hip only. The hip actuators are controlled to create a desired trajectory for each lower extremity.  The exoskeleton?s knees are passive and exhibit the basic behavior of the human knees with simple morphing of their geometries. During this hip trajectory, the knees will undergo a morphing process to ensure the stability during the stance and ground clearance during the swing. The exoskeleton knee, designed here, can be used as a low-cost artificial knee (prosthetic). Having two actuators at the hip significantly reduce the manufacturing cost and complexity of the exoskeleton.

 

2)        Stabilizing technology to ensure safety: Stabilizing an exoskeleton and its wearer (i.e., preventing fall or reducing the risk of fall) during all kinds of common daily maneuvers is a fundamental engineering task that needs to be solved before using the exoskeletons for children.  We have developed several methods of stabilization.  In one method, a mechanism was designed to be coupled to the back or front of the exoskeleton.  The device allows for all degrees of the freedom necessary for wearer?s weight shifting, however it cleverly transfers, without any distortion and modification, the forward locomotion force onto the wearer.   With the help of this stabilizing device, an exoskeleton wearer can walk stably in conjunction with a walker.  The experimental results with adults have proven that this novel mechanism substantially reduces the chance of falling.  It has also been observed that the user with the above technology is now able to freely use his/her hands to do other jobs while standing - something that is impossible to do when using crutches.  We also used a gyroscope-based stabilization mechanism for exoskeleton stabilization. The mechanism provides the necessary counteracting torque through two rotating gyroscopes. Although the control method guarantees the person's stability; however due to the large and bulky size of the device, this approach does not seem to be practical. If this stabilizing technology becomes acceptable by FDA, it will substantially reduce the rehabilitation process cost and duration since there will be little need for the physical therapist to walk with the subject.  

The technology developed through this research project, creates an improvement in the quality of life for children with mobility disorders. The technology developed here will allow rehabilitation sessions to move out of a clinical setting and into homes, reducing rehabilitation labor costs dramatically.  Additionally, the technology developed here offers an extraordinary degree of mobility and independence while decreasing the likelihood of secondary pathologies. Another technological impact of this research is derived from applicability of the stabilizer not only to exoskeleton systems, but also to bipedal robots.  The technology can also be used to further understand falls and fall risks for individuals with poor balance.
